top_comment.text:
The fission of hydrogen is impossible, and the fission of carbon does not 
net you energy.  The fusion of carbon does, though, anything that increases 
the binding energy per nucleon will do that (you can technically fission 
lithium and get an energy release because helium has so much binding energy 
per nucleon).  This seems like a pretty big oversight, should of been 
caught by your experts.  ﻿
top_comment.author: Christopher Willis

comments.text:
+kiel turner Losing a protons isn't exactly what makes a nuclear bomb 
release energy.  It is the fact that uranium is at a higher energy state 
than lead.  Or to say it another way, there is more energy needed to bind a 
uranium atom together proportional to its size than lead.  Or to say it a 
third way, if you looked a lead and weighed it and counted how many parts 
it had...and extrapolated that out to uranium...uranium would be 
unexpectedly heavier.  It takes extra energy to be uranium compared to 
lead.  The same is true for hydrogen, it would also be heavier than lead 
per nucleon.  

This is also why fusion releases energy and why you can't create a 
perpetual motion machine with fusion and fission...because iron is the 
endpoint, the energy state of iron could effectively be considered the 
nuclear ground state.  This is also why ripping apart a proton will not net 
you energy, it takes more energy to rip apart a proton than it takes to be 
a proton.  This is actually why we have matter in the first place, 
subatomic particles would rather be atomic particles given the right 
temperatures.
comments.author: Christopher Willis

comments.text:
+kiel turner
"the only difference is there are a lot more protons in a uranium atom than 
a hydrogen [atom]"

That is the point. Uranium has many nucleons (protons and neutrons), 
whereas hydrogen (in the most common isotope) has just one proton, and 
that's it. Fission of uranium breaks the nucleus apart, reducing the number 
of nucleons. "Fission" of a hydrogen atom would involve breaking the quarks 
apart. The difference is that the attraction between two nucleons is a 
residual, sort of shielded, bit of strong interaction. So, this force is 
much weaker than the force holding the quarks together. Which is why it's 
possible to fise uranium but not hydrogen (okay, while technically 
/possible/, highly impractical energetically difficult).

What's more, U235 (the uranium used in nuclear weapons) does not undergo 
decay by ejection of a simple proton. Read this (
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uranium-235#Fission) for more information.

+Scott Johnson Ex-science teacher (now research scientist) here. Scott, you 
hit the nail on the head. A huuuuge misconception that a lot of (most) 
people have is that bonds are a store of energy. This is 100% wrong, but 
things like burning wood make it tempting for people to believe it.

make some (nuclear or chemical) reactions viable and others not.

comments.text:
+zlkimagenX No, the ruler is infinite. There is no last number on the 
number line, so if there's a finite distance between any two numbers (let's 
say there's initially an integer every centimetre) then the entire ruler 
must be infinite (1 cm * infinity = infinity cm).

In this there are two length scales: 'short' distances are ones where the 
the distance between points are increasing slower than you can move (e.g. 
if the ruler doubles in size every hour, you can walk between the points 
'1' and '2' quite comfortably for many hours); and 'long' where you can't 
keep up with the expansion (e.g. the distance between 0 and a million is 
increasing by ten kilometres per hour in the first hour).

comments.text:
+zlkimagenX A good question! To answer it, let's imagine a number line, 
centred on zero. This is infinite -- goes  to infinity in either direction. 
For the sake of analogy, let's say that the points are stamped onto a ruler.

Now imagine I expand the ruler by moving each point to double the distance 
-- the place that used to have a '2' now has a '1', the place that used to 
have a '10' now has a '5' and so on. The space between any two numbers is 
now twice as large.

Now imagine I do that continuously. We would say that this is 'expanding' 
(the gap between any two numbers is increasing), but the ruler would still 
be infinite.

*"I understand what your saying  but don't at the same time"*
Welcome to the club, lol. Though I guess it would be disappointing if the 
biggest mysteries to the universe where easy to comprehend.

We only understand physics after the smallest fraction of a second after 
the big bang, when the universe first started to expand. We're fuzzy on the 
details, but this is the part of the big bang we know happened.

Before then, at time=0, we don't know what happened because our equations 
break. We can't divide by zero for instance.

The classical model of the big bang just assumes that, as we play back 
time, nothing special happened and everything just continued to compress 
into a singularity.

Since that's the part of the big bang we don't know about, modifications to 
the big bang theory (such as The Big Bounce) propose we might not have 
reached a singularity.

Either way, we say with reasonable confidence that from the first moment in 
time, energy existed. Perhaps it's easier to imagine The Big Crunch 
instead, where time would die.

It might be more intuitive to imagine how energy wouldn't somehow cease to 
exist the moment before time stopped, it would happen at the same time.

comments.text:
+zlkimagenX It's very unintuative, but it matches the data, and the 
alternatives are worse.

If there was no time before the big bang, then there was no prior state to 
have changed into the big bang. Under this reasoning, the big bang is the 
initial condition, not a change from an initial condition. The 'void' never 
existed within time.

The alternative is that time is eternal, but that goes back to your point 
about why it took an eternity to occur.

If nothing caused the big bang, and there was time for there to be a cause, 
then that breaks our understanding of causality.

If something *did* cause the big bang, what caused that? And what caused 
that cause? We end up with infinite regression, never able to reach a 
"first cause" either. Someone would ask what caused the eternal universe to 
exist, and there would be no answer.

top_comment.text: If time and space are the same thing, then what is space expanding into?﻿
top_comment.author: hellavadeal

comments.text:
The question is whether there is any such thing as space 'outside' of 
anything else.  Picture a relatively clear day after a cold front blows 
through and causes rain.  The cold air causes the denser water vapor to 
precipitate out of the air leaving sparser water vapor to condense into 
cold-weather clouds.  

Imagine continuing this process of cooling and precipitation until even the 
vacuum space between stars and galaxies was removed.  Eventually, the 
matter becomes so dense that the electrons and protons themselves condense 
into neutrons.  Keep going and the result could be single black hole that 
has precipitated all matter and energy in the universe into de-spatialized 
energy.

In other words, the universe may have no outside and even no inside.  It 
might just be a bunch of hot (energized) matter that only contains 'space' 
because it is volumized by its own energy.  If that energy would be taken 
out of it, there would be nowhere else for the energy to go.  It would 
exist in the form of a purely massive area of condensation too dense for 
anything to exist outside of it, including light.

In effect, therefore, the universe would really have no 'outside' or 
'space,' generally.  It's really just a unified field of connected energies.

If space is the most highly energized, and therefore expanded, form of 
matter; then space could be expanding into nothing but more voluminous 
space that is both more energetic and massive (because adding energy to a 
system adds mass.)

If this is the case, it would mean expanding space causes distances to grow 
among local objects but at very far distances, large conglomerations of 
expanded space would appear as black holes (and dark matter) because the 
combined gravity off all of their volume would be sufficient to prevent 
light from escaping.  

So from a point inside our hubble-sphere, distant galaxies are visible but 
the galaxies within a different hubble-sphere are no longer visible because 
all the space (expanded matter) between them and us is sufficient to 
prevent light from escaping and reaching us.  

If space is treated as a massless container, this doesn't make sense but if 
space is treated as matter-expanded-by-energy, it has mass and therefore 
gravity, the ability to bend and affect the speed of light, and thus the 
ability to absorb light (energy) and thus convert it into ever more 
expanded matter/space.

captions.text:
As you probably know by now, we’ve been
working with Google and YouTube to answer

ten of the most popular science questions
asked on the internet.

And I gotta hand it to you, because there
are few questions that are as confounding

and complex and fascinating and inspiring,
as this one the collective consciousness has
spewed forth:
What is energy?

I'm Hank Green, and this is the World’s
Most Asked Questions.
[Intro]

Energy is everything. It’s everywhere. It’s
one of the true constants of the universe,

because as long as there’s been a universe,
there’s been energy.

And while it comes in lots of different forms
that can seem different to us, they all amount

to the same thing: Energy is the ability to
do work.

And work is just the act of displacing something
by applying force.

So, say you stomp on a stomp rocket. The force
of your foot hitting the pedal is turned into

the force of air leaving the cannon -- sending
your rocket sailing.

Or maybe you're enjoying a nice patty melt
-- the energy from that food is broken down

for all of the quadrillions of cells that
you have to do all of the things that they

have to do -- make copies of your DNA, assemble
and repair proteins, transport materials from

one place to another, make muscle cells contract
-- you know, all the stuff of being alive.

That rocket sailing, your cells toiling away,
your phone or computer being on right now
to watch me -- that’s all work being done.

And the ability to do these things is inherent
in everything around you. Even things that

look inert, completely lacking in energy.
Like this log.

This log, for example, is chock full of chemical
energy because it’s made up of combinations

of carbon and hydrogen and oxygen formed into
lignin, which is the stuff that makes up wood.

All of the bonds between all of those atoms,
in every molecule of lignin, contain energy.

How do I know? Because if I were to apply
enough extra energy, like as heat, to break

those bonds -- it would release that chemical
energy as fire.

That chemical energy also the kind of energy
you get from that patty melt -- your body

is fueled by the chemical bond energy in sugars,
fats, and proteins.
But this log also contains nuclear energy!

Each atom in this wood has a nucleus, made
of protons and neutrons, and the energy that

binds them together is one of the most powerful
sources of energy in the universe.

If you could split one of the atoms of carbon
or hydrogen in this log, and rip those protons

and neutrons apart, it’d release some of
that energy. There’s so much nuclear energy

in each atom that, if I could unleash all
of it that's in this log? There’d be a giant

smoldering crater where I’m standing and
everyone in the town of Missoula, Montana
would be dead.

So, everything that’s made of atoms has
nuclear energy locked up in it, but also,

it turns out, that mass and energy are the
same thing!

You might have heard of this little equation
that a German patent clerk came up with about
a hundred years ago: E = mc2.

And there are SO MANY OTHER KINDS of energy
that I’d love to get into if we had the
time ...

.. but even though they may seem different,
they can all be used to do work, whether it’s

driving a turbine, or moving a engine piston,
or allowing the screen on your tablet to glow.

Or, if it’s that most mysterious of energies,
dark energy, causing the universe to expand
more than it seems like it should.
But here’s the thing to remember.

Once the work is done, the energy isn’t
done.
Because energy never goes away.

It can never be destroyed, and in the same
way, it can never be created.

It can only be transferred from one source
to another -- like, how the energy in the

plants and animals that were in the patty
melt were transferred into you -- or it can

be transferred from one form into another
-- like the chemical energy in the wood being
transferred to light and heat as fire.

You could think of the universe as a constant
flow of energy, and we are just little pit
stops along the way.

Everything your body is doing right now -- whether
it’s your lungs absorbing oxygen, your heart

pumping blood, your brain cells firing as
you watch me and learn things -- all those

things are using recycled energy that’s
been around since the origin of the universe.

And by simply being alive, you’re releasing
that energy back into the environment around
you, to be used by other things in other ways.

So Internet, to answer your question: Energy
is everything.

And for those of you who answered our questions
on our SciShow survey, where you feel like

you get your energy may be keeping you up
at night. Survey takers who have a hard time

falling asleep nearly every night get their
energy from knowledge first, second from purpose.
Least likely? From exercise.

Of all the fascinating questions in the world,
what question do you want to see answered

most? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or
down in the comments down below and we will

aim to answer those questions in a new video
at the end of the month.

title: World's Most Asked Questions: What Is Energy?
